 I know that Orthodox consider Protestants and Catholics to be two sides of the same coin.

And Protestants consider Orthodox and Catholic to be two sides of the same coin - Church as authority rather than Bible
 
 And Catholics consider Orthodox and Protestant to be two sides of the same coin: rejecters of the one true apostilic church.
 
 
 It's a funny old world.
 
 
 As for the reformation more generally, I think one of the most important things to bear in mind is that few set out to be 'Protestants' and break away: Luther believed his views could be within Catholicism until a Catholic showed him otherwise.
And of course through all this we have Anglicanism perched very firmly on the fence... :p

As a former Lutheran, I am quite fond of the old superstitious fool, Martin Luther. He was a deeply flawed man, yet he managed to affect a profound change in the course of European history. And, because of his exposure to some of the best education of the day, I am impressed by many of the things that he had to say.
 
 As a student in preparation for Lutheran Catechism, I was exposed to a quite balanced treatment of what was going on during the time of Reformation, careful consideration of the Calvinistic movement in Britain--I believe that Lutherans felt that the Anglican Church was flawed, based as it was on the lust of King Henry VIII and I don't remember any reference to Anglicanism, the quasi-communistic Christian movements on Continental Europe, the Hutterites, Moravians and so forth. Because the tone of the classes were slightly balanced in favor of the Continental movements I have always felt closer to the intellectual discourse of the Continent, as opposed to the many developments in the British Isles. I am trying to do a bit of catchup on Isle thinking, as witness my curiosity about Hobbes, Locke, Hume, etc.
 
 Also, I grew up in an environment where there were many Hutterite settlements and most of the immigrant population there was from the Continent.

I'm only studying the Reformation on the continent. If what happens on our little Isle is relevant it gets included, but the emphasis is on the continent.
 
 I quite like Luther as a person, because from what I've read he seems to have had a lot of character, despite having certain flaws. Examples include being called a Hussite and effectively turning around and saying "what's your point?", using the minimum eloquence possible and his responce to Philip of Hesse getting jiggy with anything that had a pulse.:)
 
 -Wez

He pretty much detested Jews as the murderers of Christ. I'm not sure how he felt about converted Jews even.

 Anti-semitism goes back a long, long way in European history. I wouldn`t say that Martin Luther was one of the causes. He might have encouraged it though (esp. in Germany)...

What I mean by one of the causes is that he actively contributed: obviously he gained it from his surroundings himself, but he spread it further and made it more vehement.
 
 Just as Hitler did not 'invent' fascism, but was one of the main causes of its rise.

 Ah, ok. I would agree with that. Even though I would also like to point out that anti-semitism was more vehement in Europe during the crusades and the black plague.

My understanding of Martin Luther and the Jews is this (again, everyone has a different take on history, remember):
 
 Martin Luther was a very political fellow and quite cognizant of the fact that he had to secure the support of a number of princes and other rulers in order to keep his skin in one piece. He tried to forge an alliance with the Jews at that time to consolidate his political power.
 
 However, the Jews were extemely wary, because they very well could serve as scapegoats if Luther failed and was destroyed by the Roman Catholic Church. Also, they probably had a deep distrust of Christianity, for very good reason, and reputedly spurned the overtures made by Luther.
 
 Luther never forgave them. I would never claim that he was a man without flaws.
 
 And, to assess the tenor of the times one must take a look at what Thomas More had to say about Luther except that most of what More said cannot be said on this forum, it is so foul.

I was under the impression Luther didn't care too much about politics or his own life for that matter. He didn't intervene in politics unless he had no other choice. For example, he left abusive princes alone and told their sub-ordinates to shut-up and follow the unfair rulers and let God cast judgement on the abusive princes.
 
 -Wez

Um, that's not my understanding, Wez.
 
 I could be proved wrong on this, let me bestir myself and do some research to support my claim, arrgghhhhh!

OK, Wez, I'm going to support my claim the quick and dirty way by stealing a quote from a book review.
 
 From an April 8, 1999 Christian Science Monitor review of Martin Luther: the Christian between God and Death, Richard Marius:
 
 
. . . .The central question Marius asks is what was it that so powerfully motivated Luther to challenge the authority of the Roman Catholic Church?. . .
One must remember that the authority of the Roman Catholic Church was solidly vested in the earthly political structures of that time and one must remember that Luther was successful in his challenge.
 
 How did he manage that? Well, I instantly deduce that Luther was an astute politician who cultivated the favor of the various princes who ruled these earthly political structures of authority. The princes of authority in the supposedly unearthly church structures were not universally loved and there was often discord between the princes of the church and the princes of the worldly realm. Luther was shrewd enough to take advantage of these differences and fallings out and establish his own authority.

http://www.wsu.edu/~dee/REFORM/LUTHER.HTM
 
 
. . . . Luther was not a person you would want to have dinner with; he was temperamental, peevish, egomaniacal, and argumentative. But this single-mindedness, this enormous self-confidence and strident belief in the rightness of his arguments, allowed him to stand against opposition, indeed, to harden his position in the face of death by fire, the usual punishment for heretics. Luther became an Augustinian monk in 1505, disappointing his equally strong-willed father, who wished him to become a lawyer. He earned a doctorate in theology from the University of Wittenberg, but instead of settling down to a placid and scholarly monkish life or an uneventful university career teaching theology, he began to develop his own personal theology, which erupted into outright blasphemy when he protested the use of indulgences in his 95 Theses. . . .
 
 In 1521, the Holy Roman Emperor, Charles V, demanded that Luther appear before the diet of the Holy Roman Empire at Worms. Luther was asked to explain his views and Charles ordered him to recant. Luther refused and he was placed under an imperial ban as an outlaw. He managed to escape, however, and he was hidden away in a castle in Wartburg where he continued to develop his new church. . . .
Obviously, Luther was given shelter in this castle by a prince of the worldly realm.

Arrgggh, the scraps of information in regard to this are so rare and small and I do not read German, let alone Old German.
 
 Nevertheless, Wez, surely you will concede that the the churchly realm and the worldly realm were tightly intertwined and that politics was a major factor in both these realms and in the intertwining of these realms.

You assume it's not a case of Luther's theological argument being strong and the worldly princes realising that they can benefit from it: he made a name for himself before he clearly opposed the Catholics, and maybe his patrons recognised that he could help them, not vice versa.

On the Jews: this is from his book 'exposing the Jews and their lies'
 
 Source, from the opening sentences of On the Jews and Their Lies:
 
 "I had made up my mind to write no more either about the Jews or against them. But since I learned that those miserable and accursed people do not cease to lure to themselves even us, that is, the Christians, I have published this little book, so that I might be found among those who opposed such poisonous activities of the Jews and who warned the Christians to be on their guard against them. I would not have believed that a Christian could be duped by the Jews into taking their exile and wretchedness upon himself. However, the devil is the god of the world, and wherever God's word is absent he has an easy task, not only with the weak but also with the strong. May God help us. Amen. 
 Grace and peace in the Lord. Dear sir and good friend, I have received a treatise in which a Jew engages in dialog with a Christian. He dares to pervert the scriptural passages which we cite in testimony to our faith, concerning our Lord Christ and Mary his mother, and to interpret them quite differently. With this argument he thinks he can destroy the basis of our faith. 
 This is my reply to you and to him. It is not my purpose to quarrel with the Jews, nor to learn from them how they interpret or understand Scripture; I know all of that very well already. Much less do I propose to convert the Jews, for that is impossible. Those two excellent men, Lyra and Burgensis, together with others, truthfully described the Jews' vile interpretation for us two hundred and one hundred years ago respectively. Indeed they refuted it thoroughly. However, this was no help at all to the Jews, and they have grown steadily worse. 
 They have failed to learn any lesson from the terrible distress that has been theirs for over fourteen hundred years in exile...." 
 From http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Martin_Luther#as_his_answer_to_an_anti-Christian_pamphlet_of_Jewish_origin

Furthermore, if one were in the religious life as Martin Luther was, one knew how to read and I am very sure that various religious movements such as those initiated by John Wycliff in the British Isles, 1328-1384, who was condemned as a heretic but not prosecuted; John Huss of Bohemia, 1369-1415, the Moravians and Hussites, burnt at the stake; Thomas Muentzer, Germany, death by beheading, 1489-1525; Huldrych Zwingli, Switzerland, 1484-1531, who killed in a battle against the Catholic cantons; Martin Luther, Germany, 1483-1546; Menno Simon, the Netherlands, 1496-1561, who died in his bed; John Calvin, Scotland, 1509-1564, were widely discussed amongst the clergy and Martin Luther very much liked being in the midst of the living and made an effort to remain in that milieu by being very aware of the politics of the realm.
 
 I would say the proof of the political pudding is in the fact that we very much remember Martin Luther and that Lutheranism is very much alive, whereas most of the others, save for Calvin, are largely forgotten even though their religious followers are still around.

Yes, and Luther was very vindictive and unforgiving. And, unfortunately, gained the power to be vindictive and unforgiving. Anti-Semitism was the tenor of the day.
 
 The Jews were a very small and powerless minority and served very well as a scapegoat for everyone. One comes away with a very distasteful view of the behavior of Christianity because of this.

Also, the wikipedia article I connected to points out that his extremism was seen as such by his contemporaries. It's like Hitler: there were many anti-Semites, but his extremes cannot be put down to crowd-pleasing, as he exceeds them (and covers it up, in the case of Hitler).

One must remember that the authority of the Roman Catholic Church was solidly vested in the earthly political structures of that time and one must remember that Luther was successful in his challenge.
 
 How did he manage that? Well, I instantly deduce that Luther was an astute politician who cultivated the favor of the various princes who ruled these earthly political structures of authority. The princes of authority in the supposedly unearthly church structures were not universally loved and there was often discord between the princes of the church and the princes of the worldly realm. Luther was shrewd enough to take advantage of these differences and fallings out and establish his own authority.

 I don't doubt Luther was an apt politician were he to put his mind to it, I do however believe he wasn't very interested in politics.
 
 Luther succeeded for a huge number of reasons, few of which he could actually influence:[*]Resentment of foreign Church influence[*]Anti-clericalism[*]Being fortunate enough to be in Frederick the Wise's land, who was powerful and comparatively open-minded.[*]The abuses of the Church[*]Appeal of religious belief to people from all sectors of society[*]Ineffectiveness of Catholic response[*]Intellectual climate (Erasmus etc.)[*]Printing presses allowing him to circulate ideas
 etc
 Luther actually tried to distinguish between secular and religious authorities, rather than the mish-mash that was present when he was young:
 
 "On his journeys to and from Worms Luther had been dismayed by the evident social and political unrest. In the next months he wrote open letters, warning the rulers of Saxony and the councils of such cities as Strassburg of the danger that the new radical teaching would provoke revolution. In 1523 he made his own views of secular government plain in an important treatise Von weltlicher Obrigkeit ("Of Earthly Government"), in which he firmly asserted the duty of a Christian prince and the place of secular government within God's ordinances for mankind; he distinguished between the two realms of spiritual and of temporal government, through which the one rule of God is administered, and stressed the duty of civil obedience and the sinfulness of rebellion against lawful authority."
 http://www.hfac.uh.edu/gbrown/philosophers/leibniz/BritannicaPages/Luther/Luther.html
 
 
 Obviously, Luther was given shelter in this castle by a prince of the worldly realm.

 He was abducted against his will for his own safety, as Frederick felt he needed protection, which he certainly did:
 
 "Luther's disappearance during his return trip was planned. Frederick the Wise arranged for Luther to be seized on his way from the Diet by a company of masked horsemen, who carried him to Wartburg Castle at Eisenach, where he stayed for about a year. He grew a wide flaring beard, took on the garb of a knight, and assumed the pseudonym Junker Jörg (Knight George). During this period of forced sojourn in the world, Luther was still hard at work upon his celebrated translation of the New Testament, though he could not rely on the isolation of a monastery."
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_luther#Diet_of_Worms
 
 
 Nevertheless, Wez, surely you will concede that the the churchly realm and the worldly realm were tightly intertwined and that politics was a major factor in both these realms and in the intertwining of these realms.

 I don't think I've claimed anything tot eh contrary.:) Luther, as I linked above, tried to separate the spiritual and the secular however.
 
 
 I would say the proof of the political pudding is in the fact that we very much remember Martin Luther and that Lutheranism is very much alive, whereas most of the others, save for Calvin, are largely forgotten even though their religious followers are still around.

 The reasons he lived were mainly out of his control however. Had he lived a hundred miles west/east/north/south, chances are he'd have been another no-one. He'd be as "famous" as Huss. Heck, had Luther not existed, Zwingli (assuming Luther didn't influence Zwingli, which is up for debate) would have fitted his boots perfectly.
 
 -Wez

From the book "Luther and the German Reformation, 1517-1555 (Keith Randell):
 
 "Such strength of feeling was limited to matters that had to do with theology and especially with theology that related to salvation. This was Luther's compelling interest and driving force. Other issues did not generally interest him, and it was with considerable reluctance that he devoted time to them. Apart from his love of music and his concern for religious-based education, he tended to venture into non-doctrinal matters on spasmodically, when his intervention seemed to be particularly called for. Otherwise he was content to allow those interested in social and political matters a fairly free rein. But he did establish very clear parameters in which they should operate."
 
 -Wez

Hmm, Wez, some very interesting information.
 
 It would seem to indicate that Luther just happened to be exceedingly lucky in the time (there were a number of other hot issues that served to propel Luther's campaign) that he turned against the Roman Catholic Church and that Frederick the Wise may have been the political force responsible for keeping Luther alive and establishing his power.
And, Frederick the Wise seems to be a verrrry interesting historical person.
